they are even goin to add the triceratops ingame, so im hyped for this, everyone has been waiting for it or yelling for a new dinosaur, im so patient on waiting new updates, dont worry devs. 
its fun growing ur dakota, because when u are young u can atleast glide and climb trees, which is easy to escape from predators for this. and people that yell that they die every time, guys just climb trees or glide away idk, or learn how to survive.
idk everything is fine in this game, the devs are slowely updating this game and fixing bugs, so people have no sense to yell at the devs, people who yells at the devs arent patient or respectfull on how much the devs are working on this game.

these was all of my opinions, but i didnt finished yet to discuss on something.
people who yell at the price, and call it ''overpricing'' its not overpricing, they did this price because its an early access game, imagine if they didnt release this game yet and u had to wait till the full fock3ng game, arent u guys already happy they released the early access thing? nah nah lets just yell                           no.

okay i finished this review, thats all i have to say and i absolutely love this game, i support this game so much, and i respect the devs that are working so hard on this. have a nice day.

review: When I was a kid, I always wanted to be a dinosaur. I wanted to be a Tyrannosaurus Rex more than anything in the world. I made my arms short and I roamed the backyard, I chased the neighborhood cats, I growled and I roared. Everybody knew me and was afraid of me. And one day my dad said, "Sammy, you're 17. It's time to throw childish things aside," and I said, "Okay, Pop." But he didn't really say that, he said, "Stop being a fu*king dinosaur and get a job."

author: {'steamid': '76561198031147622', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1549230650}
review: This game has been in Alpha stage for over a year now. I had hope for this game, as i liked the idea of just playing dinos with dinos without having to be a mmo, but sadly it falls short. After all this time there is still only one playable dino, and it is nearly impossible to get full grown. Food is scarce and a constant thing you have to search for.  Dinos are way to few, really needs a larger variety and many more dinos to interact with. Maybe in several years this will be a fun game but its not anywhere there yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198442050933', 'num_games_owned': 415, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1675466165}
review:
If you want a short review then I will say. One of the best games I've played.
That's subjective because I'm an paleo fan. I have been fascinated by dinosaurs since I was little.
This game is still buggy and there has to be a lot of polishing before the final product. But slowdown for everyone's sake. Game development is a hard task that can take a long while depending on the game. I would say that the finished product will be released around 2022-2024 and that's a generous estimate. It's not due laziness but because of a small team. 

I read a lot of reviews that are irrelevant for example. "I can barely run this game"  is one of the reviews I read and it boiled my blood because the where on the store page.  People also say "The only objective is to somehow kill without being one shotted." I have a question if you ever have seen an documentary where the weaker animals didn't get one shotted? It's survival of the fittest not an random dinosaur who has super dinosaur strength. In this game you're not special just another dinosaur in a world of Slight mentally challenged dinosaurs. Just like mine most of these reviews are subjective. Try to find an objective. In fact you can't trust reviews anymore nowadays and I'm also not asking for you to trust me.

Gameplay is fun but also tedious at times. The only sad part that I can think of is that the game is too easy. Just keep hunting small prey and go to the drinking hole from time to time and you will be fine. Actually the fact that some parts are too easy is because thanks too realism. I ran towards an T.rex an he didn't attack me because he wasn't hungry. And that's realistic. I wish you left some kind of trail behind that predators could follow or that the crocodiles would sit in ambush for when an animal comes to close to the water.

If I had to list dinosaur games then this game will be on top. And to the people that noticed my text being all over the place. Good job!!! I'm mentally challenged myself and this review is a laborious task  for me. Now I will go back into the darkness and keep supporting Saurian and Urvogel. And also buy the guide to Hell Creek. Have a good day. Also may the dino be upon you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118323926', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1602609094}
review:
Played as a Dakotaraptor on the realistic difficulty.
Managed to grow to age 7 by sticking near the river and killing smaller or same size prey.
Got to confident and engaged a Triceratops.
My first two jumps on it where successful and caused some damage.
On my third attempt to jump I most likely tripped or something resulting in me hitting the side of Triceratops like some brickwall snaping my neck and insta killing me.

Would snap my neck again 10/10

Thought to be honest the game tends to get a bit boring as you wonder around searching for prey and water. There are no other preditors that would really chalange you as you can easily take them on or simply run away.

I would only recommend this game to people who are big fans of dinosaurs otherwise there isn't much to do in this game but to wonder around aimlessly with no goal in mind.

And for those people that whine about this game being to difficult - GIT GUD.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141330634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1702420233}
review:
Is it worth it?

Yes, absolutley. I've been following Saurian for a very long time, and when I first got it it was not so functional, filled with bugs, and very plain. Coming back to saurian now there are tons of new features, interesting and varied NPC AI, still a few clipping issues but that is to be expected with a pre-alpha game.

They have been working on, they have released new content, why haven't they released the other dinosaurs? Well, coding them to be as fluent in movement as the Dakotaraptor whilst being controlled is going to be tough (or so i'd think). Please give this game the chance and the support, they are working on it and adding good content. I understand why people are hesitant because there has been a trend with steam and pre alpha games but I've been following this one the same as I followed Subnautica, yes at times it is slow but its amazing and well worth the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060634115', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1547319113}
review: Probably the worst alpha game I've ever played. Its basically UNPLAYABLE. The current point of the game is to somehow kill something without getting one-shot by everything (even in casual difficulty) as the birdythingy your first meal will liely be your dead parents to a alligator because even though they are x4 its size they lose to the alligator 10/10 times. So you eat them, maybe kill a fish and a lizard then you realize... Hey there is nothing to do between meals. So you camp the body and eat. Sleep to age up. Repeat. All to try to unlock the other dinos and likely do the same, but being bigger? idk Its not looking promising at the moment...

author: {'steamid': '76561198152772204', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1460, 'last_played': 1684470477}
review:
LET ME JUST SAY NOW: This game is in early access, so this review is only for the game in it's current state, I honestly love Saurian but I can't recommend it in it's current state. The devs are working very hard and I get that but this is just my honest review, I've always wanted a game like this.

-The Game-
Graphics: Pretty good, not the best of the games I have but up there.
Models: The models honestly are a bit on the bad side, at least for the T. Rex and Dakotaraptor as of now. The other models are not the best but this game is in EA so I expect them to become much better in the future,
Animations: Honestly? It depends. On the new Ankylosaur they put into the game most of the animations arent bad, but it's tail swing animation is horrid. I'm sorry but compared to all the other creatures' animations it's just bad.
Skins: As of now you can only choose one skin for the only playable creature as of now, but I'm hoping it gets better.
Gameplay: The gameplay is very immersive besides the AI, which they are working on very hard, and I understand it's an EA game but the AI still needs improvements to it. Besides that it's very realistic as they've gone for and the game is pretty fun to play WHEN YOU BUY IT AT FIRST. Once you complete the growth one or two times it gets very boring, and right now only 1 out of 6 playable creatures are out and it will be awhile until they are all out.

-The Community-
Forums: Very helpful from what I have seen, I haven't gone to the forums much.
Discord: From the time I've talked in it, the moderators for the discord and the people in general are very nice and helpful, if you have a question they will help you if they can.

-The Developers-
The devs of this game are actually very nice, they help their community if/when they can and are really working hard for it to become the game they showed us in the trailers. They release "dev blogs" from time to time showcasing what they've working on for the game.

OVERALL RATING: 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198046304165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1645509999}
review:
I've been watching Saurian's progress almost since its first steps, and playing since the very, VERY early days. Back when the game was little more than a showcase of the (then-laughable) AI, the Raptor Prey Restraint mechanic, and a pretty but empty map. Almost three years after backing the Kickstarter, and about six years into the overall development, I finally feel like the game is starting to shine enough for me to recommend giving it a try. But I must preface the praise I'm about to vomit with this:

Saurian is most definitely not for everyone yet. As an early access title, it's plagued with bugs and performance issues, which can make the game all but unplayable until they're patched. Updates are fairly slow to come out - hell, I love the game, and I usually end up putting it down for long stretches while I wait - and often wipe your progress when they do. This long after it was funded, you still only have the option of playing as Dakotaraptor, and the next playable dinosaur is still quite a wait away. You can grow to adult size in about two hours, leaving you with little else to do but explore your surroundings. In addition, while multiplayer was funded as a stretch goal, the game is years away from that stage. If you want more variety, you're better off waiting.

That said, Saurian has a number of things going for it.

- The environments are absolutely stunning and full of life. With every update that adds new AI creatures, it feels more and more like you really are taking on the role of a predator in an ecosystem. The dinosaurs and other animals are equally well modeled and animated - except for the odd animation glitch.

- You start out as a small and tasty snack for bigger predators, but you're not helpless. You are dangerous to the things that are smaller than yourself, even as a hatchling. The inclusion of small prey and the targeting and scent mechanics make it much easier to survive as a young Dakotaraptor than it used to be.

- Even if you run into trouble, the AI will not pursue you if you flee far enough away. In addition, young Dakotaraptors can evade predators by climbing trees.

- Your hunger, thirst, health, stamina, and growth meters are easy to keep an eye on. Progression is also easy to follow, as you grow steadily over time, and the game will prompt you to sleep when you're ready to advance to the next growth stage.

- When you get big enough, RPR is your intended primary method of hunting. It's much improved from what it was when the mechanic was first showcased. Once you get the hang of it, you can hunt most of the creatures around you with little difficulty - there are even cases of people killing the newly-included Anatosauruses. (Note: Your size determines what you can and should hunt.)

- As you grow, the AI creatures will respond to you in different ways. Things that would hunt you when you're young will react defensively or run away when you're an adult. In addition, creatures that would dismiss you as not being a threat will become aggressive towards you or flee, temperament depending. They will also fight back if you attack them when you're small.

- The dedication to accuracy is unprecedented. From the animals to the foliage to the location itself, the team is determined to bring us the most up-to-date, well-researched dinosaur game we've ever seen. While some things about the game are speculative, such as Anzu's planned vocal mimicry, there's no question that the devs are passionate about paleontology and bringing an extinct ecosystem back to life.

Right now, I do believe this game is worth at least picking up on sale. When Saurian is a fully realized game, I believe it will be an absolute marvel. Until then, if there's not enough content to keep you invested, it's perfectly fine to wait.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003561282', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 264, 'last_played': 1611195939}
review:
I'm tired of reading reviews for this game that explain how people havent read the description of it. Dummies...

Thay say they dont plan to update the early access until roughly Aug 2019 yet people are commplaining throughout here about how there arent any updates or there is only the one creature to play....OK...It's in early access and they state they dont plan on updating it untill its more or less complete. Estimates around Aug 2019 by the math.

That out of the way I both like and dislike the game. I really like the controls and graphics(I love me some eye candy), but the power level discrepency is hard to deal with. That combined with the lack of interesting things to explore/experience make for a fairly strong hit in the negative. Overall though I would say if you are a fan of survival games and dinosaurs I think you will enjoy it once it is finished.

review: I really like how Saurian sticks to Scientific accuracy and stays away from the dinosaur appearances imprinted on us by Jurassic Park especially since A LOT of dinosaur based games that aren't even related to JP, use similar anatomy and reconstructions as Jurassic Park such as incorrect hand posture in Maniraptorans, The size of Velociraptors and sometimes a lack of feathers on dinosaurs with feathers such as Utahraptor and Dromeasaurus

author: {'steamid': '76561198243627248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1655583455}
review:
When I saw this thing, I imidiately asked my dad to support it. Its been out for a year and a half. It was delayed by 8 months, and the stuff they put in the game then is still the only content remaining. Sure they've added a bit of stuff, like the mosa. and... Thats the only big thing really. They keep showing us how cool their game looks through the dev logs, but we don't get to play with any of that stuff. They keep trying to keep their models realistic, but T.rex is going to keep changing its apearence over and over again, so just make that game how you were gonna do. So that we can play something other than your most boring creature. Why can't we play as a t.rex? Why can't we play as a trike? WHY CAN'T WE PLAY AS ANYTHING YOU PROMISED! I was really looking forward to this game. But at this point, I'm not gonna touch it until you add something interesting. NOT PACHY. Multiplayer would save your game, because right now, you're only gonna loose more players. This stuff isn't that complicated. Stop with the scientific acuracy for just 2 months. Then your game will actually be good. You're charging 21$ Canadian on this thing. Its a tech demo. 

I hope this game actually becomes what it wants to be before 2050.

sorry devs. I know you work hard. But enough is enough.

If you're thinking of getting this game, wait until its an actual game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198269062803', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 199, 'last_played': 1677610828}
review:
Love it! Amazing graphics, and a great approach to dinosaur world simulation that strikes a very good balance between realism and fun. The game looks like it's still in early development, and it has some limitations and issues (e.g. only one playable dinosaur at the moment and unpredictable/unexplained controls when trying to kill larger prey), so if you're looking for a finished/polished game, this is not it yet. However, what's there is amazing!

I think the developers have taken the right approach by providing only one playable dinosaur for now and focusing on perfecting it before throwing in a dozen dinosaurs just to make early players happy. Also, although the environment already has quite a bit in it, I assume the developers will improve on that too by adding some environmental challenges (an erupting volcano at some point for example) and improving AI for other predatory creatures such as the crocodilians in the water (which never sneak up on you at the moment) before final release in order to keep gameplay interesting.

P.S. I tried two other similar looking dinosaur games/simulations before this one and hated both. This one fixes everything I thought was wrong with the other two, and I think it has great potential to become *the* dinosaur simulation for people who're looking for a fun and realistic dinosaur world experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025151914', 'num_games_owned': 231, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1542998033}

author: {'steamid': '76561198098807293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1690, 'last_played': 1602653795}
review: I rarely write reviews but for Saurian I decided to write one. I have never had more fun in any other game then this gem. To me, Saurian is an exploration of to an ancient world. The most accurate simulation to the lives, actions and sights of animals we find fossilized in our modern day Hell Creek Formation. Sure I did everything I could at the moment due to it not being fully finished but as the devs continue to add more, i get a feeling similar that of a newborn Dakotaraptor, exploring the complex ecosystem filled with unique flora and fauna. This game will take time to be filled but why rush things, i respect the teams choice to do their research and bring to us what is the most accurate representation of that world. A representation that only could be rivaled by the eyes of the very animals it portrays when they lives in that world all those 66 million years ago.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078739317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 750, 'last_played': 1611208506}
review:
To be clear I do enjoy the atmosphere of this game, and I do think it has a lot of potential; however, there are a few issues with it. 
It's been in production for a while now, with no end in sight. Updates are few and far between. At the rate it's going, I can't imagine this game being done for another couple years. I could be wrong, and I'm not judging the time it's taking. They're an indie developer and game production takes a long time. There's only one playable out of the 5 or so planned. Not to mention the game is mostly unplayable for most people unless they have a high end PC, and even then the game is not pretty to look at.
What I am judging them for is some of their 'science' and the behavior of some of the devs. 
Many believe this game to be the pinnacle of scientific accuracy, the gold standard. While some aspects are pretty accurate, a lot of other areas are not, and it should all be taken with a grain of salt. I appreciate the attempt, but it's an impossible task to be 'scientifically accurate' with this stuff; but don't dare question the scholarly authority of the devs on the matter.
I can't say all the devs have some questionable PR; nevertheless, there has been some unprofessional handling of critics from some of the devs. For example: one slandered my friend. This same person also said some questionable things to me. I would hope to see a little more professionalism. 
For these reasons, I have a hard time supporting this game. In spite of my personal bias, my main reason that I can't recommend this game to others is that it's far from complete, with no end in sight.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047341050', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1548779759}
review:
First off is this game worth it? Yes and why? I will give you my opinions. (2018/10/28)

What makes this game so outstanding good from any other dino survival games that are out now is the quality over quantity of the gameplay and models because here we have a dinosaur game that is highly focusing on a the closest and updated scientifically accurate depection of the dinosaurs and the enviroment at the late cretaceous period that once roamed our earth like how can you not resist a game like that.

I do also wanna say some of my opinions of people writing against this game and what some of the things you should know about the game and it's developers.

Just because this game has been out for more than 1 and half a year doesnt mean it should be out of EA (earley acces) and been a properly working game. Because working on a game is a hard work especially with game mechanic we havent seen and experienced before plus also the working time of these developers are only on their free/spare time because as i said previously here they prefer quality over quantity of their game and they rather have much added plans and fixed bugs they can release out in a big worth waited patch. 

Yet people still complain about the devs arent working hard enough on the game which i hardly disagree on because here as i say some part of it again they doesnt have this game as their full payed jobs to work on yet. They work this game on their free/sparetime they got in their real life and most of them are volunteers that hasnt had any game working experince and still learning to work on it because they are all sharing the same common goal to make this a "Good enjoyable game for everyone" which i am happy to see and play on.

For thoose of you that still reading this review if you planning on getting this game now or later but you wanna stay updated about the game i would highly recommend joining the Saurian Discord Server or Follow the game on steam to stay updated. Thank you for your time and have a good day/evening.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078978305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1619054027}
review:
Ignoring the low fps (I blame my computer for that) this is a really fun game so far! I'd definitely recommend it to dinosaur lovers, but maybe advise others to wait until full release to play it, as there isn't much to do game-wise besides hunt, avoid agressive animals, & run around.
I experienced a few golden moments (like a couple other species teaming up with me to fight a croc that was being a bully) and that alone makes this game worth playing pre-alpha, lag and all, as it's interesting to see how other animals react to you & the things you do around them. Can't wait for updates, & it's definitely gonna kill me to wait for full release--I'm so excited to see the finished product!

author: {'steamid': '76561198413679897', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1572381591}
review: The game itself is a game worth buying, considering the fact that it's only in the prerelease stage. Wich says alot about its potential in the future. I purchased the game a while ago, and have had no problems what so ever. I am, however, experiencing a problem at the moment, and I'm not sure if anyone else that owns this game is having this problem. After the release of the latest update. The game's resolution has become really poor. When I opened the game to try it out. Nothing seemed to be out of the ordinary. It was when I started a new game, that the resolution went south. Now when ever I launch the game, the resolution on any screen of the game, not only in the gameplay, is really poor. I can hardly read anything on the screen. I've tried to go to the settings to see if maybe something was changed. But it's no use. I can not read anything. I have also tried to uninstall and reinstall the game (twice) but that did not seem to work either. I am in no way trying to badmouth the game or the developers. I am simply trying to see if I can get the problem sorted out. I highly recomend the game, as long as things run smoothly while playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198841678532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1538923420}
review:
Saurian looked great and wanted to buy. My system met all the requirements and that was great but the graphics went to shit and I wasn't able to fix it, so I had no choice but to opt to refund. If the devs would fix this, it would be great. It looked fine when I first downloaded it but no sooner than I clicked on the encyclopedia, that's when it went to the dumps and I was not able to fix it.

Surprising really, as I met all the system requirements and I have a NVDIA GeForce GTX 1050 Graphics card, so it should NOT have done this... Maybe it was the processor? 

Here is mine; Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-7300HQ CPU @ 2.50GHz, 2501 Mhz, 4 Core(s), 4 Logical Processor(s)

Any help would be great. I will give a thumbs up to be fair, but this needs to be fixed asap.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095868313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1602352738}
review:
Oh dear.

After about a year of being unable to play this game I finally got a decent computer which could manage various other high graphics titles (JWE, ZT:UAC etc), and Saurian finally seemed to be working. Then the space bar stopped working... and then all the save files got corrupted. And as there is no other way of tracking progress that meant going strait back to hatchling stage. And bear in mind the only reason I died and tried to reload the save was because of the poor combat controls and my inability to jump and escape up a tree.

Guess I'll have to wait another year to try again then

author: {'steamid': '76561198091954799', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1536646142}
review:
I put off writing a true review for this game in the hopes that there would be some major improvements.  I very much realize I have not spent countless hours playing, however my issues are the fact that it has been over a year and there is still only a single playable dinosaur.  There were 4 dinosaurs promised to be playable by the release of the game, which I understand hasn't happened yet, however after a whole year you think they would have been able to make more progress.  

I was really excited when this game was first announced, even backed it on kickstarter, but at this point it's just a disappointment.  I get that we're still early access, but I very much expected more for the time frame the 'pre-Alpha' has been released.  If you were in on the hype of the day, you would have thought they would be full access by now, but they haven't even begun to even get close to releasing the other 3 playable 'main' dinosaurs not to mention all of the stretch goals that were funded.

I've now shelved this game twice while I wait for some major development updates.

UPDATE 9/1/19:  Oh, guess what!?!  A year later and STILL ONLY ONE PLAYABLE F-ING DINOSAUR.  This dev team needs a serious boot in the rear and should be abysmally ashamed of themselves for duping the masses like this.  No one should buy this game and I feel like the recent 'positive' reviews are strictly from people who just bought the game and enjoyed their 3 hours of running around as a raptor.

I would say this game should never have been released in the state that it is in, but the truth is the devs are the ones to blame for their lack of progress.  They need to pull their heads out and buckle down to deliver on the promises they made during their kickstarter.  This game should have been fully released by this point and it still not even a beta.

author: {'steamid': '76561198183613130', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2300, 'last_played': 1603162288}
review:
Saurian is a beautiful Game and is really unique. People have the opportunity to live the life of a dinosaur as close as possible.

 You start as a hatchling in the world and have the choice to rather stay with your parents for a while or to directly explore your environment and find yourself something to eat. But that’s not all, of course you have to [b]survive[/b]. There are many predators who will be trying to kill you, also including your own kind. So you have to be constantly watching out what’s around you, even plant-eating dinosaurs can be dangerous. The water is also not the safest place to go because crcocodilians will be protecting their territory there. You can prefer to be hunting on little lizards and birds at first but when time goes on and you slowly grow up it won’t be enaugh to be filling your hunger, so you have to begin to hunt larger prey. It will be challenging but once the prey is down it is going to be worth the effort. 

I really appreciate the work the developers put into this. They want to keep everything as accurate as possible and this is not easy. Every plant, every tree, every environment, each little detail on the dinosaurs and the look of them in general has a scientific explanation. Everything you see in this game is real and has really existed 66 million years ago. 

The design and the models of the dinosaurs are really good, original and detailed. The Graphics are also really beautiful. Unfortunately, my graphics card (940mx) isn’t really able to show these at 60 fps but it’s still enjoyable. For me the environment really feels like I’m in the nature, I don’t know why, but it just feels so relaxing, quiet and beautiful with the mix of sounds of the small animals and the wind. Trees are also mixed and the same ones aren’t used too often at the same place like you would see it in other games. The Animations, man, they looks really good aswell. So smooth and realistic. Each feather is moving on the feathered dinosaurs when they are walking and running.

Of course the game has some bugs as an Early Access Game and I am totally okay with that. My problem is just how slow the game has developed over the past year. We only got a few more AI Creatures, some more abilities and the Dakotaraptor still is the only playable dinosaur in the game. But because the concept of the game is so unique I’m still going to be supporting and following it. The game itself is awesome and I would recommend it to anyone who is interested in how the dinosaurs really lived.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069037802', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1563437630}
review: Absolutely love the concept of this game, taking dozens of different scientifically accurate prehistoric animal species and throwing them all into a realistic survival setting. Of course the main issue as of now is still the framerate, but i'm postive that this will be patched in the future. I still am very glad that I spent the money, though, as I want to see how this game develops. I mean, they've even got an emu on the development team, that's gotta count for something!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008113755', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1089, 'last_played': 1609341956}
review:
Don't take this as an actual review, most of it is blabber. In real this game is great a solid 8/10 so far. I'm just saying stuff I don't like. This is one or the best dinosaur simulation game out there.


The Ai is highly agressive, and mindless. Your parents will just wander around no clue, and just try to kill pachies and die. Good source of food. The herbivore Ai is very bad. Pachies just attack you when you go by them. Those ostrich bastards are also very annoying, they go in groups of 6-10 and when you attack them, they just make an orgy around you and consume you, pecking you that does about 1/12 of your health. Doesn't seem like a lot but it is when you're consumed by 8 of them that peck you endlessly. Crocodiles. CROCODILES. Those fricking messes, the just sit around in the middle of the river, and very easy to avoid. And when they do come on land, the small gator can sometimes SWIM ON LAND. This should be in bugs, and it wil but still, just ugh. Nothing really else to say, others just ignore you until you attack or threaten them.
Next part, This game is pretty good but runs horrible for a person who can run Far Cry Primal with a solid 60 fps. So I lower the res, and it looks terrible, people will say, "It's not about the graphics! It's about the experience and gameplay!" I know that but It ruins the gameplay for me.
With some more playthrough I'm now a Super-Adult, I can kill those Emu things quite easily with my pounce. That's antoher thing to talk about, pouncing. I like It, It's just hard to follow. Saurian devs don't want everbody to be a spamming pouncer Ik, but it's so hard to control which way you go honestly. It's like a joy stick, but all messed up. Up goes right, down goes left, left goes up, and right goes down, I'm getting confused at this. Next time I'll come back and talk some more probably when another dino comes out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198371253121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2, 'last_played': 1532738708}
review:
I got [i]Saurian[/i] a few days ago and... well, it has a lot of potential. The game is still in Early Access and has been in development for nearly a decade, supported in part by a GoFundMe. By no means is this unpolished clusterfцсk a masterpiece--although it absolutely could be one if its developers continue to put in the amount of effort and passion they've been showing for their project over the years. Maybe I'm biased because I like dinosaurs, and because dear god how I've longed to play as one in a video game--but [i]Saurian[/i] just appeals to me on a personal level.

Enough gushing, though.

What, exactly, is [i]Saurian[/i]? Well, if you're absolutely stupid and haven't checked it out before reading this, Saurian is a third-person survival game set in the prehistoric Cretacious era. It actually depicts a real place, the Hell Creek Formation, with its inhabitants being based on actual fossils paleontologists have found at at the location millions of years later. The dinosaurs that you see and play as are ones that actually lived alongside one another in that location, and their behaviors are reconstructed from evidence recovered there.

The main goal of the game is to survive as one of four dinosaurs (now with feathers!): Dakotaraptor, Pachycephalosaurus, Triceratops, or Tyrannosaurus Rex (I've heard tell of Anzu wyliei and Ankylosaurus magniventris being added in the future as well). At this time, though, only one of the playable species is available--the Dakotaraptor.

Each dinosaur, from what I've come to understand, has a unique and different set of biological needs, predators, prey, and innate abilities. For example, Dakotaraptor hatchlings, which are small, can shimmy up trees to escape danger; an incredibly useful trick. Older raptors can perform a technique known as Raptor Prey Restraint, which involves latching on with the sickle claw and using their bodyweight to exhaust the prey's stamina.

It's very satisfying to pull it off for the first time--trust me on that.

Carnivores also have the ability to smell predators and prey around them, which is very useful when hunting--though some animals, like crocodiles, don't give off a smell and have to be avoided by keen observation.

[i]Saurian[/i] provides a real sense of an organic food chain. It is possible to encounter rotting carrion, to watch animals hunt one another from afar, and to be eaten by other animals yourself. There is even another species of raptor, Archaeoraptor, which will hunt hatchling and juvenile Dakotaraptor for food. As another organic-feeling element of the world, age plays a role in predator/prey relationships. The Archaeoraptor is the predator for the first two stages of growth, but as your Dakotaraptor grows bigger, it becomes capable of hunting the hunter.

As a hatchling or juvenile, most larger herbivores will not react negatively to your presence unless you attack them--but they will react poorly to the presence of an adult Dakotaraptor. Perhaps the coolest thing you can do in your first two stages (in my opinion) is follow a T. Rex around and scavenge its kills, since you're too small for the Rex to bother with and most larger predators won't go anywhere near it.

Survival in [i]Saurian[/i] is typically governed by four basic meters:
Your Health (obviously if this gets to zero, you're dead)
Your Hunger (you fill your stomach by eating your dinosaur's required food)
Your Thirst (go to the water and drink to refill, but watch out for ambush predators)
Your Stamina (this is quite high, but offset by the slow regen rate)

Pretty basic stuff. Your stamina is also affected by your sleep, or lack of it.

Additionally, there are statuses for things like envenomation, as there are creatures in the area that are venomous (For the love of all that's decent, stay away from the big monitor lizards when you're a baby!). As an adult, you generally won't have to worry so much about those things if you stay healthy, but if you're starving or sickly, it could do some serious damage.

If you get killed and hit 'retry' it restarts you from the last time you slept, while increasing your hunger by 25% or so. Once you've exhausted all the food you've eaten or died a certain number of times, you'll start losing health rapidly. If you don't find something to eat quickly, you'll die. Unfortunately, in Saurian, this is very difficult to do, especially if you've gone the wrong way at some point. Food is scarce and hard to come by.

This brings me to the part where I talk about bugs I've found and ways the game could be improved. It's still in Early Access/pre-alpha (people have told me different things) so it's clear that there's a lot of room for change, and I hope these things can be improved. [i]Saurian[/i] is a fun game, but it's also very hard to play sometimes because of all the issues.

The biggest issue was the sheer heat it generated. I have eleven mini fans, a box fan, and an ACU unit running to keep my computer cold, I'm using the absolute best tech I can possibly afford (1070 ti with the fan clocked up to 100%), and I still had my PC's CPU hit up to 99 degrees. Even [i]ARK[/i] didn't do that. I'm not really sure what the issue is, and it may be coming from my end, but--when I tried turning down the settings to compensate, I discovered that there was only one setting to turn down and it didn't actually affect what it should have affected.

Oy vey.

Now, some relatively minor issues.

I think there should be some hints about sticking to the coast as a hatchling, as going inland always led to my starvation. Food for the first two stages in general is incredibly scarce to the point where I think it should be a bit more common, maybe by an increase of 15% or 20%. That's only my opinion, though.

It would be nice to have the secondary attack be available out of the RPR context, albeit in a different form. I may just be saying this because I play too much [i]Dark Souls[/i], but it would be cool to be able to do combos with a raptor claw. Again, just my dumb opinion. It's also possible that the secondary is independently available and I was just having problems because I mapped it to an XBox controller (don't judge me).

This one is fact, though: the tree climbing animation needs to be re-done, as it suffers from a massive amount of clipping and just looks bad overall. Players and NPCs alike will sometimes slide down slightly tilted surfaces when not moving. The AI isn't very smart and will sometimes try to endlessly run into solid objects such as trees or locations that are too steep to climb. We know dinosaurs were bird-brained, but this is excessive.

There is almost no music at all, but I'm sure that's in the works.

Saving is a bit spastic. I don't really know how to describe it. Half the functions I mapped to my controller don't actually work, though again, this may be a problem on my end. Jumps aren't very fluid as there seems to be a break between the jump animation and the resting one, leading to a rather sudden aerial presence. Jumping is unreliable, too. Depending on the area of the map, you can jump ten feet in the air or two feet. It's very frustrating at times.

I'd write a lot more about [i]Saurian[/i], but I'm running out of space because Steam doesn't like big constructive reviews. Thanks, Steam.

tl;dr [i]Saurian[/i] is a game that's still being made, and thus it's broken and bugged as hell, but what we've been able to see so far is amazing. Despite its flaws, I would definitely recommend Saurian to anybody (preferably when the final version comes out, of course).

author: {'steamid': '76561198068800902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1532948567}
review: For an Early access game it's not bad. Saurian has its issues such as the "combat" not being all that great (such as you need to bite a little lizard multiple times before it dies yet you get one shotted by an animal that's smaller or roughly the same size as you). The bugs in the game aren't the game breaking variety but can be very annoying and sometimes the FPS goes all over the place. Yet despite these issues I find Saurian rather fun to play, it's a frustrating game but the good kind of frustrating where you feel a sense of satisfaction and accomplishment after overcoming an obstacle. So do I recommend this game? Yes but maybe wait until the Triceratops is available as a playable dinosaur and the devs fix up some more of the game.

review:

Ancak bu oyun daha Erken Erişimde, ve Erken Erişimden çıkınca fiyatının ne kadar olacağını bilemeyiz.
Evet fiyatı artacak çünkü daha çok dinozorlar ve yerler gelecek.
Benim tavsiyem oyunu hemen alın, kendinizi Dakotaraptor'da geliştirin ve canınız sıkılırsa bırakın ancak yine de kütüphanenizde dursun.
Bence bu oyunun Erken Erişimi bittiğinde oyun Primal Carnage: Extinction ve The Isle'dan daha güzel olacak.
Kısaca önceden alın; faydasını Erken Erişimi bitince veya yeni dinozorlar eklenince göreceksiniz :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198041029798', 'num_games_owned': 98, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1549232367}
review:
I desperately wanted to love this game.  If properly done, this could have been one of the greatest games that I have ever wished for. Unfortunately it has flopped immensely. 

The game was so hyped, and for what?  

The first thing you'll likely notice when starting is the incredibly poor optimization.  The game's fps is terrible, even on many high-end machines.  You can make all the pretty flora and fauna you'd like but when you move and everything looks like a slideshow, no matter what graphic setting you choose, will ruin everything.  

The animal's animations are sub-par at best.  While the adult dakotaraptor's looks decent, the hatchling's animations are awful.  It's head tracking makes it's neck look stiff and broken and it's trot animation is almost comedic to watch.  

The controls in general are also clunky and odd as well.  Adding a climbing mechanic didn't help any, as the controls and the gliding feel terribly awkward.  Fighting is unsatisfying and...well, I'm running out of new adjectives.  Awkward is the word for that too.

AI is generally not impressive and honestly mostly a joke.  Follow your parents when you begin and you'll see what I mean.  Your parents will die, usually to the first thing they encounter.  For a game like this, AI should be of utmost importance as it is all you have to interact with.   Instead, AI are mindless and robotic.  

The game has beautiful models and I appreciate the accuracy of the realism but the developers need to look at the functionality of their game over everything else.  It's in sore need of optimization and fine-tuning.  Updates are slow and they've implemented little to the game as a whole.  The structure of the game itself needs addressed before more is built upon it, otherwise nothing will change for the better.

At this pace, the game will never amount to much more than it is now, and it'll be multiple years before all the playables are added( not that more playable creatures will suddenly make the game great).  

If the game still looks, runs and feels like it does now, well, it won't be bustling around here, that's for sure.   Maybe it's time for some more professional help for the developers?  Surely someone with more experience can do some good to help fix the core mechanics and issues we're seeing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198300862658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'last_played': 1639331575}
review:
Disclosure: I contributed to the campaign to have this game developed.
As of now, no, I don't recommend this game if you need to pay for it. It's nowhere near prime time. Maybe if they just dropped the game aspect at this point and let players roam freely and not die at the drop of a hat or constantly need to search for water and food. Becomes monotonous very quickly and the controls are clunky. I appreciate the amount of science put into this game, but you don't have enough time to explore and enjoy it without something hurting or killing you. The poor implementation of the game engine also requires you to have a beefy system in order to play it at half decent quality levels. The longer development drags on, the more unlikely that what you see right now is all it ever will be.

There are lizards but most the time I can't catch them lol. Even though it isn't quite what I was hoping, I'm still keeping the game as I'd love to see it develop more. I'm excited to play the other dinosaurs when they come out!

author: {'steamid': '76561197964241602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1588863897}
review: I've been waiting for a game like this for decades! As an avid dinosaur lover, it is so amazing to finally play a game where I can finally BE one that is accurate and SINGLE PLAYER!! I've grown tired of human vs dinosaur multiplayer. Hell, I'm tired of being human. Spending a few hours as a fluffy raptor trying to survive is perfect for me after a long day. The fact that a lot of thought has been put into the dinosaurs, fauna, and landscape makes the paleontologist in me happy as well. The game is still a little glitchy and I've had minor problems with clipping and odd AI behavior, but it's still a work in progress and I trust these developers will deliver.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010039690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1577403716}
review:
I saw that this was a realistic dino game and that was enough of a sell for me. I REALLY wanted to like this. I truly did. But after loading up the game and playing for a little bit, I was severely disappointed. Even the highest graphics setting doesn't look good on my machine. In my first two games, I followed the adults. Both of them died. In my third playthrough, I followed my sibling. He reached the water, drank from it, and then just kind of melted into the water and died. So I took off on my own, hoping for an adventure. Instead, I found myself wandering a very empty world. I couldn't find food anywhere for my dakotaraptor chick. Just other creatures that immediately killed me when I tried to attack them.

This might be worth it at this stage of development for $5. But 20$? Definitely not.

Edit: I kept this game hoping against hope that there would be more development. Over a year after writing my original review, nothing has changed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009739783', 'num_games_owned': 474, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1530388319}
review:
As a dino enthusiast, I wanted to support this project since a long time now but couldn't afford it, and I'm really happy to have been able to do this now AND actually get my hands on this copy.
Yes the game is full of problems, but this is just a demonstration and I cannot see how people can get angry in some revious for just a pre-alpha video game when right this moment we could still be waiting for a kickstarter project that might never come out. Even if this game fails, I'm more than happy to have tried it. Following the research and work of this super small team for a while and seeing how much efford has been put into making this as historically accurate as possible, I'm actually impressed they made it so far.

You a dino fan as well? You tend to keep an open mind with low expectations and test implementations like that?
You wanna support a project that takes the idea of feathered dino to a whole new level?
Are you willing to donate money on a cause that bring the most realistic idea of dinosaurs in a video game to date?

Then this is for you. Don't see it as a pledge. See it as a piece of support for something that finally takes us away from the scary lizard like Jurassic Park dino culture and introduces us to a reality where dinos can still be awesome and interesting even if they are fluffy af.
Get your hands on the first implementation of dakotaraptor and enjoy your self a simplestic but interesting simulator that even with all of its bugs and issues, is actually an educationally piece of work that has so much potential if it ever recieves more support.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3E7HxK130Ec

author: {'steamid': '76561198071928390', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1530536735}
review:
I do not really 'not' recommend this game, but it's honestly barely a game right now. I've been following Saurian for years and decided to finally get into it. I've always wanted a realistic dinosaur simulator, preferably multiplayer but this could also be fun. I go into the game and immediately I notice the awful frame rate. I thought others who complained about it were just playing on bad computers but even on mine, which is a gaming computer, it is barely functional. You really can't hunt properly because of how bad the frame rate is. As a baby Dakotaraptor I had no idea what I was supposed to hunt, I could not find any small prey at all so I relied on trying to find bigger dinos to hunt for me which brings me to the AI.

The AI is laughably bad right now. So many times I found AI dinos just standing still or walking into trees/rocks/etc. They do not pay any attention to me at all unless I get right up in their face and bite at them. Which brings me to my next complaint. I got bored very quickly. Between how empty the world feels, the lack of things to hunt and the awful frame rate making the game look like crap I eventually just stopped playing seriously and just went looking for things to kill me. 

All of these issues, I assume, will be fixed in time. But I was disappointed with the lack of progress they seem to have made over the last year and where this team's priorities seem to be. So focused on realism they are they seemed to have forgotten game play is also important, I'd argue more important. 

Saurian is definitely worth keeping your eye on. There is great potential here for sure. But as of right now, from what I've played. It's not worth paying for and I sort of wish I could get my money back. But at least I got it on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986296269', 'num_games_owned': 879, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1530533647}
review:
how did you make being a dinosaur not fun? I mean I can see the answer.... there is no wait button, there is no guarantee that there will be any dinosaurs around you at any given time. the "combat" is non existant. so I am this young raptor and I can either kill tiny lizards for food and die of boredom. or I could challenge a larger animal and die instantly cause I collided with it's head or leg.

movement controls are bad and clunky framerate is abysmal. feedback is non existant, I never know if my bites even deal damage, and the bites don't seem to interact well with the movement, which would surely suck if you re supposed to chase down prey. I don't think there is a dodge button. if you see an animal they are masterful dodgers, just scare a cat. it ll jump backwards. why would you not have a dodge button? you have wings!! you can use the wings to propell yourself backwards to dodge that little bit faster. I should be able to harass the bigger dinosaurs bite them once and flutter back like a demon chicken. there is a feature where you can jump on teh back of your prey aniamls but I don't know what buttons to press to not fall off.and then you die instnatly if you fall off cause the aniaml will bite you. another point where a dodge button would be helpful.

 also it takes like 5 minutes to add colliders to an object in unity. why can I clip through the trees???
I am thinking the reason why things don't have colliders is because the movement controls would interact extremely poorly with any type of collider that isn't a straight wall. sure sucsk that yyou clip into other dinosaurs... I mean they literally don't even collide. you can walk right through.

I love little more than learning about dinosaurs, but it seems you ve done nothing with it. the scientists  helped you make everything look good, but it's wasted on this non game.

Also the bonehead dinosaurs should deal damage only by running into things fast. they shouldn't instant kill you if you touch them while they arent even moving. get some damn speed based combat going.

I didn't get to grow up cause I kept dying... well the game isn't fun and the progress to growing up is unclear so I guess I ll never know how a fully grown dacotaraptor plays.

author: {'steamid': '76561198371030355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1527719079}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049117293', 'num_games_owned': 850, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1549072786}
review:
I've always wanted to play as a dinosaur, so when I saw a youtuber play this, I decided to get it and I've been enjoying it so far, though I am aware of the bugs it currently has. 

The graphics are beautiful and makes me feel like I'm a dinosaur living in the Hell Creek formation of the past. I like the sounds the dinosaurs make too.

There are a few bugs I've encountered; I've noticed that even on the lowest setting of graphics, I lag for a split second every so often. Mind you, my computer's specs are slightly above the recommended level. If possible, the developers should lower the value of the graphics for the lowest setting and maybe the second-to-lowest setting, so we won't experience any lag. Or give us the option to edit the graphics individually.

When I loaded a save file, I was immediately attacked by a predator, but I dashed away before taking any more damage. My health bar was at zero, yet I was still alive. I couldn't bite, drink, smell, etc. Other predators couldn't even kill me. This is a bug I think the developers should look into, especially with the damage that inflicts onto you and to whoever you're attacking, as some of the reviewers mentioned.

A couple of things I'd like to see in the future are more dinosaurs spawning and the option to start a family. The world feels rather empty without a variety of dinosaurs in large numbers inhabiting it, and I'd like to have more things to do, other than run around and hunt.

If you're a dinosaur lover and want to play this game, I suggest getting it. But be aware, this is an early access game, so it's not finished yet and you'll likely experience some bugs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008919217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1602398024}
review:
This game has an amazing concept and has a very passionate team behind it. 

What currently exists does have a lot of potential and the developers release a blog every two weeks to keep you up to date of their progress. That being said, the game's development is definitely going slower than some people may like, they are a very small team and can't make big sweeps like bigger developers can. What we have here is a game that will one day be great if it keeps on its course, but will require some patience to get there.

I'd definitely say it's worth giving a go, but please note that after you reach adulthood with the Dakotaraptor, your relationship with this game going forward will more be checkimg back in on it every few weeks\months to see what's new has been added, rather than enjoying it as a deeply fulfilling experience - it's not there yet, but you can see how it probably will get there given time.

Recommended if you like this concept, but with a large patience disclaimer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158279120', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 5139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5139, 'last_played': 1530475035}
review:
I actually do enjoy many aspects of the game such as the music, environments, and slow paced peaceful gameplay pacing.
 
But right now it is not worth the money, first off it doesn't run too well but this is to be expected from an early access game. The worst thing about it is the combat and interactions with AI creatures. The AI is supposed to behave in convincing and realistic ways, but instead acts idiotic, overly aggressive and suicidal ways. You'll never start a game without your AI parents attacking some random dinosaur on sight only to get pummelled in the face or going into water and deciding swimming around in circles forever is more important than survival. Additionally the devs seem to have made everything unrealistically stacked against the player, with the player dying in one or two hits from something that is the same size as you or even smaller, as is the case with the small gators. Even as an adult most of your intended prey can either kill you in a few hits, or takes 500 hits to kill. It doesn't help that your mouth often misses your target due to bad hitboxes. It is disappointed to be one-shotted and overpowered by similarly sized creatures and never be able to inflict the same damage on other creatures.

So much for a realistic dinosaur simulator when your man-sized raptor dies to a lizard 1/4th your size that takes 20 hits to kill.

I still am hopeful that this game will be more fun and realistic in the future. I suspect it will be, but for now I'd recommend against getting this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198207920787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1170, 'last_played': 1654475860}
review:
People need to cut this game some slack, the devs are a small team, and this isn't like Ark, it's supposed to be scientifically accurate. Check out their page and you can see why adding more dinosaurs take so long, they are trying to program herd systems for the triceratops and other dinos. The devs are modeling every leaf on the trees and 

For early access this game has given a lot. The soundtrack, models and gameplay is better than other dino simulators I've seen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012104404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1646432433}
review:
It's a very cool concept and is fun....for a little while at least. It might just be me, but it seems to be surprisingly difficult to survive. I realize that's the intent of the game, but it's not super fun (in my opinion) to die all the time. I've played 4 hours of the game and still can't figure out the killing system. I've only been able to kill lizards and birds so far, which are few and far between.

I do experience quite a bit of lag while trying to get around as well, which doesn't help. The game doesn't seem that intensive compared to other games I run with no problem (GTA 5, Far Cry 5) so I'm stumped on that one. I have also had to restart several times because of some bug upon loading the game. It plays the "you died" sound and my camera is fixed somewhere in the sky. When this happens, there's no fixing it, it becomes unplayable. I started up a new game just now and it was extremely laggy for some reason, despite not changing a single setting, again making it unplayable. 

I really wanted to like this one. It's got a beautiful environment and great character models and animations. There seems to be a lot of potential with everything, so I'm still hopeful for what the future will bring. For now, I'm going to have to shelve it, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198408603365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1600222344}
review: I love the effort that has been put into making as accurate a depiction of Hell Creek as possible. It is the only game of its kind. I really enjoy having to think through a strategy for survival and understanding what that implies for my place in the ecosystem. This is a great game. Thank you Saurian.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168497247', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1598538623}
review:
I hadn't played Saurian since a few months after it released. 
Excited to see what changes have been brought about and what new content was available, I loaded up the game and gave it a try. And what I didn't expect was that it was all so completely, astoundingly... Disappointing. 
A game that had been on steam nearly a full year, and it felt like little to nothing changed at all. A few new mechanics, some new animal AIs wandering around, and that's just about it. Almost one year of development, and what did we recieve? Some half-baked mechanics that hardly ever work properly, and a handful of new creatures that aren't playable and have 0 impact on your gameplay experience.

So what do you do in Saurian? 
In Saurian you can choose one of four dinosaurs(Dakotaraptor is the only available choice atm) and you can spawn into the world as a hatchling, then attempt to survive the prehistoric ecosystem until you grow your way to the top. 
In the game, as your little raptor, you can fight your prey by pouncing atop it and tear it apart. You can also, as a juvenile, climb trees and glide between them. All this time the prehistoric world goes on around you. 
You'll see herds of herbivores grazing, carnivores stalking the jungles and shorelines, and if you're lucky, you can become to top predator.

Sounds cool, right? Except that the game doesn't feel like a world. All of the animals act exactly alike. Well, almost exactly alike. 
As far as I can tell, the AI has two different reactions to seeing your character. Kill it or run away. More often than not, you'll find the AI completely ignores you. Or the AI is completely suicidal. 
Giant herbivores will charge in and get obliterated by tiny crocodiles instead of running away. Triceratops will graze endlessly while you literally stand there and bite them to death. 
That is of course when they aren't randomly walking in circles, walking into walls or trees, or swimming out into lakes and rivers for no reason to get slaughtered by the tiny one-shot crocs. 
The AI is on-par with ARK: Survival Evolved's AI. And that's not good for a game like this that relies so much on the world to sell the experience. 

Speaking of the world. How does it look? Well honestly, the world looks and runs like garbage. They claim to have put so much effort into the plant life of Hell Creek, but ingame it just looks awful. As for the optimization? It's almost nonexistant. 
Nearly one full year has passed since this game was released and it doesn't feel optimized at all. I'm normally not hard on optimization in games because of my PC's build, but this is ridiculous. 
I can run most of my games at over 60fps, and in Saurian, on mixed settings, I can barely keep above 15 frames. No matter the resolution, the world still looks blurred and fuzzy. It's not an enjoyable experience. 

Overall, the game is just disappointing. Completely and totally disappointing. The dev team feels uninspired to work on their game, I mean look at their dev logs. There's little to no content present in them and the explainations of what is being done behind the scenes is almost nonexistant. 

I'll be checking back with the game in a few more months, but I can't be optimistic anymore. This game is a good example of a good concept with indescribably poor excecution.

author: {'steamid': '76561198727832081', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1041, 'last_played': 1650180216}

author: {'steamid': '76561198011095485', 'num_games_owned': 298, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1529813048}
review:
Honestly, I don't know what it is about indie/first time developers and Unity, they must get a discount or something with regards to the tool suite because every EA dev out there seems to use this engine. Getting past what Unity does and can do leaves you with this game and every other Early Access Unity title to have ever blanketed the Steam Store. Ugly visuals. This is not to say Unity can't look great, it really can. The visuals Unity can render can be absolutely stunning (eg. Escape from Tarkov). You just need talented people working on it.

Focusing on the terrain, the one thing that should pull you into the world, immerse you into an environment and plant its hooks in you is utterly disappointing. The textures are all low-res and the models and sprites rather terrible. I mean I can see and count the polys on the trees and the terrain when its sloped. That's unacceptable, especially for a game and map that's been in development well before it launched its Kickstarter.

On the other hand the dinosaurs, AI, most of the anims, and social behavior systems are actually pretty neat. But this is the problem with first time developers working from a Kickstarted program. That being talented people in one area of game design and not so talented people in the others. This is the crux of the issue in my opinion with regards to Saurian and other EA titles. 

Couple these aformentioned problems with updates/patches that emerge possibly every 2-4 months, what seems like limited dev-community interaction via Steam, old and outdated FAQ's, a nonexistent roadmap, haphazard and at times ugly visuals, and limited actual gameplay components, this just isn't something I'd recommend to anyone in its current state.

Now, this isn't to say it won't improve over time, even drastically. Maybe they'll redesign, fix, and improve and beautify the flora, fauna, and terrain? I don't know. But given how rare meaningful and content rich updates seem to occur I wouldn't hold my breath. 

I would love to see it succeed and I'd love to change my review down the road. I just don't see that happening.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006687252', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1585435343}
review:
A fantastic idea for a game, for an early access title there are already many good features and you get a complete experience to enjoy (playing as a Dakotaraptor from hatchling until adulthood)

I'm disappointed to see a few poor reviews recently, the game is in early stages, there hasn't been any optimisation yet so it will run a lot more poorly that it is going to at launch. This is all part of what an early access game is, if you can understand it's a work in progress and wish to support these awesome developers then I highly recommend it. 

Just remember to turn your graphical options to low in order to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007818316', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1512313944}
review:
I rarely admit that a game is laggy enough to be unplayable (I have played Fort Zombie), but this one is. Moreover, there is just a small bunch of dinosaurs to find in the world, not much of a gameplay and even less of any scientific sense, not mentioning abscence of immersion.

With all my love to dinosaurs, this one made me believe spore-like games and dinosaur simulators are either dead or won`t be seen in the nearest future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159952854', 'num_games_owned': 309, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 226, 'last_played': 1693779209}
review:
虽然我很喜欢恐龙类游戏，但是这个游戏你连食草龙都打不过太过分了吧，好歹老子也是个吃肉的，只要有一个失误被食草龙咬了两口你就死了，都已经十几岁了还这么低的容错率有毒吧。真不知道我为什么要买这个游戏受气。

新手可以刚出生的时候把自己兄弟咬死，但是肉别一次性吃完，吃两口喝点水，直接长按c睡觉，醒来了再吃几口然后去找吃的。

刚开始你只能杀死小蜥蜴和小鸟，小蜥蜴一般在在草食龙多的地方，小鸟在湖边会落下来，数量不多。大蜥蜴不要去惹你也打不死，嘴里有毒前期咬一口必死。

有一种和我们一样大的小龙你也别惹，品种不一样人家已经成年了，一两口你就死了，通常是黑色的嘴比我们尖，看到就跑。

当你两岁的时候你就可以跳到别人背上去了但是没用立马就掉下来，掉下来了没有体力两口就被咬死了。年龄按esc键右上角有，当你年龄增加他会提醒你睡觉升级

现在可以上树了，对着树空格按shift可以加速怕，躲肉食龙有用，按空格就跳下来了。

草食龙一个打不过，随着你的身体渐渐长大你就有一种错觉，感觉自己可以把这个龙杀死，告诉你都是假的，你屁都杀不死，虽然你在别人背上站的时间越来越长但是只要你一掉下来人家也就是两口的事。

傻逼游戏优化差的一批1060显卡开最低画质还会卡而且经常卡死。别买这个游戏

review: This game is fun to me. Not a, hey I’m gonna play this for several months fun, more of a, hey I wonder how this has progressed! And then I play it for a few hours. If your looking for a huge commitment game, as of right now, this isn’t for you. If you want to play as a dinosaur and not have to think about other players ruining your game (I’m looking at you The Isle) then this may be a good buy. You can also wait to see how it progresses, that said people seem to always forget that games usually become more expensive when released, so if you want this game for cheap how’s the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198808986607', 'num_games_owned': 92, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1654747148}

author: {'steamid': '76561198838301468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 1542, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1624198606}
review:
Saurian is a beautiful experience of stepping straight into the late cretaceous period. The level of historically accurate detail the devs put into this game is astonishing. I really cannot wait to see the final version of the game and be able to play a few more dinosaur species. 
The added tree climbing, gliding and battle damage really has begun to show the progress to a polished final product. 
Without a doubt the most paleontologically accurate dinosaur simulation game on the market.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972463354', 'num_games_owned': 887, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1644175440}
review:
Je n'ai pas vraiment beaucoup d'heures de jeu, mais c'est logique car dans le jeu il n'y a presque rien à faire pour le moment. Si je mets une note négative, c'est que ce jeu c'est beaucoup de hype à la base pour pas grand chose. En effet, les mises à jour arrivent 1 à 2 fois par an et ces mises à jour n'ajoutent pas spécialement du contenu pour le moment.

Je soutiens pleins de jeux en EA donc je comprend bien comment cela marche et qu'il est toujours en cours de développement. Mais une fois plus sur Steam, on nous met en EA un jeu qui est plus dans une phase de "concept" plus qu'une EA à proprement parlé. L'idée est bonne, mais clairement le contenu actuel ne justifie pas 20 € et encore moins lorsqu'il y a 2 maj par an.

Nous ne sommes pas sans nouvelle cependant, il y a des devlogs régulièrement mais si vous êtes du genre à vouloir sur une EA profiter d'un jeu, reporter des bugs et tester de nouvelles fonctionalités, passez votre chemin, il va falloir attendre. 
Donc pour moi c'est non, le concept est bon, la réalisation pas mauvaise du tout mais bon après avoir fait mumuse 1h avec on tourne en rond et vu la vitesse à laquelle il se développe...

author: {'steamid': '76561198240775324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 446, 'last_played': 1602613927}
review:
Nach einem holprigen Start ins Spiel durch ignorieren der Infos (die Oben links eingeblendet werden) die anscheinend das Toturial darstellen , ein sehr interesanntes Spieleprinziep als Schlüpfling über die Jugend hinaus bis hin zum Erwachsenen Dino. Mal eine ganz neue erfahrung aus richtung Survival. Denn es heißt fressen oder gefressen werden (gesetz dem Fall man ist ein Fleischfresser :P ). Das Spiel mag zwar noch keine richtige Story beinhalten, trotzdem ist es sehr fesselnd. An sich ist das Spiel sein Geld wert ABER man sollte diesen sogenannten (raptor-angriff) nicht mit spamen der li.taste und re. taste der maus ausführen sondern eher mit der Maus selbst das Gleichgewicht ausbalancieren und dann den üblichen Angriff über die li. maustaste ausführen.

Ps: ich hoffe das Urvogel Games weiter an diesem tollen und mega interesannten Spiel weiter Arbeitet und hoffentlich bald weitere Dinos freischaltet zum spielen

author: {'steamid': '76561198095641976', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1674959151}
review:
I've been obsessed with dinosaurs and prehistoric life ever since I was 3 years old.  I found out about this game through Trey the Explainer and I backed it on kickstarter on a whim.  Sadly, I have to say I'm very disappointed.  I want this game to be so good but the developers keep confusing scientific accuracy with fun.  Look, I'm all for scientific accuracy in my dinosaur game.  That's definitely important to me but not to the point where the game isn't fun!  The devs keep promising updates but they prioritize keeping up with science above all else.  There's no way they can make a 100% accurate dinosaur game because our understanding of these animals changes so rapidly through each passing year.  If you think you can make "the most up to date dino sim ever," it's just not going to happen.  

I think the devs kind of forgot that science is about making mistakes and learning from them.  It's really okay to make some mistakes in the game because like I said, there's no way they can make this game as "up to date" as possible.  I think the devs need to take this attitude because this game will NEVER be finished if they keep changing the details of the paleontological science in Saurian.  

The game looks good but it doesn't perform well at all.  I have an i7-6900k with a gtx 970.  I know that this isn't the greatest setup by today's standards but my setup should be able to handle this game because it surpasses the minimum hardware requirements.  Optimization needs to be the second big focus in Saurian because right now it stutters and has frame dips that make the game very unpleasant to play at the moment.  

I guess my dream for a fun dinosaur sim will be unfulfilled for now.  If I was the lead director on this game I would prioritize complex ai for sure.  Having AI that's unpredictable would make the game very intense and immersive.  Say for instance you run into a T-Rex that's very territorial and you're playing as a Dakotaraptor.  It starts defending it's territory because it made a kill or it's creating a nest.  If the AI in this game was more intricate then I think we'd have a better game on our hands.  Maybe a storyteller would be a good idea too!  If any of you guys have played RimWorld you'll know there's a storyteller that adds random events to your game which keeps you on your toes at all times.  That would be sensible in this game and it would really help break things up from eating food and drinking.  

On the whole, I really hope the devs read our reviews because the idea behind this game is a great one.  It's just that the execution is poor in Saurian.  It's all well and good to make a dinosaur sim that's grounded in science but this is a game at the end of the day and games need to be fun!  This isn't fun sadly because of it's grindy focus on surviving with little to no purpose outside of "don't die."  I respect the devs who are working on this game but they need to get their fingers out of their ears and start listening to the community.  This review will change when the game is more updated and most of all, entertaining.
